channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: G7 Leaders Promise 1B Doses of Coronavirus Vaccines
item.description: The IMF has raised its global growth forecast, but Georgieva noted that "economic fortunes are diverging dangerously" and more equitable vaccine distribution and support for lower-income countries is needed. Besides one hilarious mixup over uneven gifting, the headline announcement was a pledge to send 1 billion Covid vaccine doses to lower-income countries through Covax, the joint initiative of the WHO and the Gavi vaccine alliance.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 14
item.description: (Reveal)  Read: Where did the microchip vaccine conspiracy theory come from anyway?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: June 14
item.description: Father's Day is on Sunday (the best present you can give him is to let him watch golf). Biden + Putin: The heads of the US and Russian governments will meet on Wednesday, the final day of Biden's first overseas trip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: MLB Expected to Address Sticky Stuff Controversy in Coming Days
item.description: Pitchers themselves aren't exactly pushing back. Well, the advantage pitchers gain from the sticky stuff may be contributing to one of the most pitiful batting displays in baseball's long history. Boosting offenses and maintaining what’s left of MLB’s integrity is critical to the long-term success of the league.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Gaming's Preeminent Conference, E3, Is This Weekend
item.description: Big picture: Sony and EA are skipping the showcase. E3 has been losing exhibitors and, some argue, relevance ever since its ’00s heyday when, for instance, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr went on stage to promote The Beatles: Rock Band. ? A coincidence or... Nintendo could use tomorrow's announcement reel to finally unveil a new-and-improved Nintendo Switch.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Make It Work: Balancing Work and Life
item.description: Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021.  —Lily I find I am constantly overworked and lack a proper work life balance. How do I find my work-life balance at this company? You need to start setting expectations for yourself and for your coworkers that some parts of the day are off-limits for work matters. Comp questions can be really hard to navigate! The safest bet is to provide a salary range that would work for you.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: What If I Have Shares in a Non-Public Company?
item.description: It’s way easier to sell your shares if and when your company goes public or is acquired by another company. There are eBay-like marketplaces for selling private company shares, but it’s not like posting a picture of your old iPod and offering free shipping.  If you want to sell your stake before the company goes public, you can ask the execs at your company to buy back your shares.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 12
item.description: (LA Times) Read: A pleasant story about everyone’s favorite courtroom TV star, Judge Judy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The G7 Summit Led to a Lot of Awkward Photos

item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Didi Chuxing Leads, What Could Be, a Record Breaking IPO Summer
item.description: On Thursday, Didi Chuxing, China’s largest ride-hailing service, filed for a US IPO at a reported $70 billion valuation. Bankers are forecasting that US-listed IPOs could raise up to $40 billion from June through August this year, topping last year’s record of $32 billion, per the WSJ.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: House Lawmakers Drop Five Antitrust Bills on Big Tech
item.description: A bipartisan group of House lawmakers interrupted Summer Fridays across the US yesterday afternoon by dropping five antitrust bills designed to finally put some speed limits on the tech industry’s autobahn. Mergers: A fourth bill would make it more difficult for Big Tech companies to snatch up smaller competitors. Conflict of interest: Huge tech companies wouldn't be able to own or operate a business that would incentive it to favor its own products over those of a competitor.  Those new lawsHere’s a quick look at the major themes of the five bills lawmakers dropped yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Gaming’s Preeminent Conference, E3, Is This Weekend

In general, E3 has been losing exhibitors and, some argue, relevance ever since its ’00s heyday when, for instance, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr went on stage to promote The Beatles: Rock Band. ? A coincidence or... Nintendo could use its announcement reel to finally unveil a new-and-improved Nintendo Switch.

item.title: House Lawmakers Drop Five Antitrust Bills on Big Tech
item.description: A bipartisan group of House lawmakers interrupted Summer Fridays across the US yesterday afternoon by dropping five antitrust bills designed to finally put some speed limits on the tech industry’s autobahn. Mergers: A fourth bill would make it more difficult for Big Tech companies to snatch up smaller competitors. Conflict of interest: Huge tech companies wouldn't be able to own or operate a business that would incentive it to favor its own products over those of a competitor.  Those new lawsHere’s a quick look at the major themes of the five bills lawmakers dropped yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Boring Company Says "Open Sesame"
item.description: And the now-operational Las Vegas Loop is proof that, at least to an extent, he is capable of turning stuck-in-traffic musings into reality, even if it is "basically just Teslas in tunnels at this point," as Musk himself admitted. The Boring Company's Loop in Las Vegas can transport up to 4,400 passengers per hour. Skeptics question why Musk is digging tunnels to shuttle people around... And it can ferry a lot more people than the Boring Company's system currently can.  In all, it was a rather, uh, boring debut for The Boring Company, a venture Musk created after he became fed up with LA gridlock."
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers with… Insecure's Yvonne Orji
item.description: Before I went in to pitch my show for Oprah, back in 2015, my roommate was like, "Do you have a hype song?" It's unclear what people talked about in group chats before Insecure graced us with its hilarious plotlines, juicy drama, and, of course, Emmy-nominated Yvonne Orji. I would love to be in my car, feeling down, and then look up and see a billboard that says "Why not me?" If you could write anything on a billboard, what would it be?" I was like, if this older white man and this older white woman can sell gazillions of books [by] pretty much talking about faith, why not me? Why not me?
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Netflix's Next Big Plan to Win Streaming Wars: Merch
item.description: Netflix has done collabs with retailers including Walmart, Sephora, and Target to sell clothes and other branded items from its most bingeable shows, but this is the company's first step into selling those products itself. The streaming service launched Netflix.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 11
item.description: (New Yorker)  Read: The dark, democratizing power of the social media stock market. Three members of the advisory panel have now quit following the decision.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden, G7 Leaders Meet to Discuss Covid, Climate, and More
item.description: Biden follows up the G7 with a NATO summit next week and a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, whom he’s expected to confront on issues including cybersecurity. G7 leaders are expected to announce they'll be giving 1 billion doses out in the coming year.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Goldman Sachs Tells Employees to Report Their Vaccine Status
item.description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has mentioned multiple times that it's totally legal for companies to 1) require vaccines and 2) ask about vaccination status.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: US Economy Heat Check: Ghost-Pepper Hot
item.description: Wealth: US household wealth climbed to a record $136.9 trillion in Q1 thanks to rising values of stocks and homes. Driving the price increases were…Airfare, food, and beefHousehold furnishings, boosted by a record price increase for floor coveringsBut mostly used vehicles, which accounted for a third of May's total price hikes2. Consumer prices: They jumped 0.6% from April to May and 5% from last year, the fastest annual increase since 2008.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Economy Heat Check: Ghost-Pepper Hot
item.description: Wealth: US household wealth climbed to a record $136.9 trillion in Q1 thanks to rising values of stocks and homes. Driving the price increases were…Airfare, food, and beefHousehold furnishings, boosted by a record price increase for floor coverings. Consumer prices: They jumped 0.6% from April to May and 5% from last year, the fastest annual increase since 2008. When you compare prices to 2019, they rose just 2.5% in May.Prices are rising the most in the sectors that got hit the worst by the pandemic (transportation, hospitality, apparel).
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Reportedly Planning Its First Smartwatch
item.description: Yep, Facebook is prepping an Apple Watch competitor, according to The Verge. Because the fried chicken sandwich market is a little too saturated, Facebook is planning to release the next best thing: a smartwatch. Looking ahead... Zuck is so bullish on high-tech glasses that he once predicted they’ll become as common as mobile phones.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 10
item.description: (Flowingdata) chicken. Look: at everything we’ve eaten since the ’70s and see the dramatic rise of... The $370 million Margaritaville Resort Times Square is opening next month.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden Repeals and Replaces Trump’s App Bans
item.description: In just the last week…Biden banned US investors from funding 59 Chinese companies, including tech giant Huawei. When TikTok seemed to be just hours from disappearing from app stores? The Senate passed a $250 billion bill that invests in American science and technology to challenge China’s growing economic ambitions.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Everything You Need to Know About Delta, the Covid Variant Racing Around the World
item.description: A variant known as Delta is gaining Covid market share in many countries and raising concerns among public health officials. Where is Delta? Delta is also in the US, where it accounts for 6% of all cases. Bottom line: Vaccines appear to be highly effective against Delta.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: After More Than 12 Tortured Years, Keystone XL Pipeline Is Officially Canceled
item.description: “We remain disappointed and frustrated with the circumstances surrounding the Keystone XL project, including the cancellation of the presidential permit for the pipeline’s border crossing,” Alberta Premier Jason Kenney said.   Supporters of the pipeline said it would create thousands of well-paying construction jobs and bolster US energy security. “It's a great day for Mother Earth," Larry Wright Jr., chairman of Nebraska’s Ponca Tribe, said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: After More Than 12 Tortured Years, Keystone XL Pipeline Is Officially Canceled
item.description: “We remain disappointed and frustrated with the circumstances surrounding the Keystone XL project, including the cancellation of the presidential permit for the pipeline’s border crossing,” Alberta Premier Jason Kenney said.   Supporters of the pipeline said it would create thousands of well-paying construction jobs and bolster US energy security. “It's a great day for Mother Earth," Larry Wright Jr., chairman of Nebraska’s Ponca Tribe, said. Environmentalists and others who opposed the project, meanwhile, are overjoyed that their years of public advocacy paid off. Canceled.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 10
item.description: (Flowingdata) chicken. Look: at everything we’ve eaten since the ’70s and see the dramatic rise of... The $370 million Margaritaville Resort Times Square is opening next month.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden Repeals and Replaces Trump’s App Bans
item.description: In just the last week…Biden banned US investors from funding 59 Chinese companies, including tech giant Huawei. He tried to force ByteDance, TikTok’s China-based parent company, to sell TikTok to a US company, leading to a Bachelor-esque competition among powerful American corporations to buy the app and access its vast Gen Z consumer base. Other plans Trump made for TikTok also never became reality. When TikTok seemed to be just hours from disappearing from app stores?
item.author: Neal Freyman
